If possible, i'll try to phrase this correctly, what is up with the difference between Morellonomicon and Executioners? Mages have to wait till 40% of the target health is left, but Marksmen get to apply it anytime without any limitation?

The difference is in the intended way mages and marksmen interact with other champions (outside of laning where grievous wounds won't usually come up). In general mages are built to burst down their targets while marksmen are built to deal a steady amount of damage until their target is dead. Thus, steady healing has a significant impact on a marksman's success in fighting a target but has a much smaller effect on a mage's success (if you deal %100 of your target's health at one moment, no amount of healing will save them, if you deal it over 10 seconds the amount they heal per second is very significant to the health they have at the end). With this in mind it makes sense for marksmen to apply grievous wounds at full health because if they don't healing will have a very significant effect. On the other hand, mages only need to apply grievous wounds when they have already bursted their target (IE their target is below %40) to prevent their work from being undone. This difference does have some awkward consequences such as making AD assassins (like zed, yasuo, and talon) somewhat better at harass and AP sustained damage carries (like ryze, azir, or kassadin) somewhat worse at dealing sustained damage, but overall the system makes sense.

TLDR: Grievous wounds for mages keeps targets low after a burst combo, Grievous wounds for marksmen keeps targets from regenerating the steady damage they deal.

I've been playing on the PBE and have loved how the new masteries have buffed Soraka.  Her heals are increased by 10%, her self heals and health regen increased by another 8%, her heals increase the target's armor and magic resist by 15% (whole team if you use your ult), and the 45% CDR means her W heal can pop every 1.1 seconds.  Also, the masteries give her a bunch of extra health regen, helping her recover between heals.  It's awesome.
